title: Ticket #6535: ClassAd python objects has case-sensitive __contains__
description:
In python, you can check for existence of keys in dict-like objects with attr in dict, implemented by a class __contains__ method. ClassAd objects allow checking for attributes this way but it's case-sensitive, whereas all other methods of accessing attributes are case-insensitive: 

#!/bin/env python

import htcondor
import classad

coll = htcondor.Collector('localhost')
ad = coll.locate(htcondor.DaemonTypes.Collector)

# these all access the 'Name' attribute
print '\n'.join([ad['name'],
                 ad['Name'],
                 ad.get('name'),
                 ad.get('Name'),
                 str('Name' in ad)]) # True

# this fails to access 'Name'
print 'name' in ad # False
remarks:
2018-Oct-09 09:55:20 by johnkn:
It looks to me like since our Classad wrapper doesn't have a __contains__ method, python falls back to getting the keys and then iterating to see if one matches.

the keys iteration is implemented thus 

    typedef boost::transform_iterator<AttrPairToFirst, classad::AttrList::iterator> AttrKeyIter;


    ...


    AttrKeyIter beginKeys();
    AttrKeyIter endKeys();


    ...


   .def("keys", boost::python::range(&ClassAdWrapper::beginKeys, &ClassAdWrapper::endKeys))

It looks to me like python is just doing it's own comparison of a string against the iteration of keys. So we can fix the first example by adding a __contains__ method (and we should since it's more efficient). But 

    key in ad.keys()

would still be case sensitive. (I think)

2018-Oct-10 09:58:04 by johnkn:
Upon consultation with some other python programmers, it is not a problem that 

    key in ad.keys()

is case sensitive

2018-Oct-10 15:35:59 by tim:
CODE REVIEW Nice addition

DOC REVIEW Complete
